text: Hello people, I am having trouble installing new Julia packages. My Manifest.toml or Project.toml might be corrupt. Is there a way to reset these files somehow? Thanks you

elements.text: Hello people, I am having trouble installing new Julia packages. My Manifest.toml or Project.toml might be corrupt. Is there a way to reset these files somehow? Thanks you

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

in which environment?  the global one or a local one?  deleting the `Manifest.toml` should be mostly safe.  but what error do you have _exactly_?  was the manifest generated with a different minor version of Julia?

text:
Is there a local one, as well? I thought the only one in:
_C:\Julia\Julia 1.5.2\bin_
The error I get is:

`julia> import Pkg; Pkg.add("ModelingToolkit")`
  `Resolving package versions...`
`┌ Error: Could not parse entry for `LinearAlgebra``
`└ @ Pkg.Types D:\buildbot\worker\package_win64\build\usr\share\julia\stdlib\v1.5\Pkg\src\manifest.jl:146`
`ERROR: MethodError: no method matching get(::Pair{String,Any}, ::String, ::Nothing)`

and I was told that perhaps the Manifest or Project were edited by mistake

you can create as as many local environments as you want, and that's often a good idea, instead of polluting the global environment

text: unfortunately Pkg errors aren't always very helpful: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/1853>  until they give more information about _what_ is the faulty manifest/project, good luck with finding it

text: if you see my bug report above, the issue was in a devved package I recently modified (and I made a mistake).  it may well be the case also for you, but you have no clue from the error message alone

elements.text: if you see my bug report above, the issue was in a devved package I recently modified (and I made a mistake).  it may well be the case also for you, but you have no clue from the error message alone

text: Yes,  I just read it, so it seems that issues in a local package under development can hinder Julia functionality, even when spawning in the global environment?

elements.text: Yes,  I just read it, so it seems that issues in a local package under development can hinder Julia functionality, even when spawning in the global environment?

text: well, if the package _is_ in your global environment...

Indeed it is, I just found it is contained in the global Project.toml.  Interesting!
Alright, I will try removing it and see if the error persists. Thanks again
